description: From Middle English ballokes (plural of ballok), from Old English beallucas (nominative plural of bealluc). Synchronically analyzable as bollock +‎ -s. Compare cullion.

entries.meaning: (Britain, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, vulgar) The testicles (sometimes used in the singular)
(Britain, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, vulgar) Nonsense or information deliberately intended to mislead.
examples: That's a load of bollocks, mate!

entries.meaning: (Ireland, Britain, Australia, New Zealand, vulgar, used as singular) An idiot, an ignorant or disagreeable person.
examples: Don't mind him; he's only an oul' bollocks!

entries.meaning: (Britain, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, vulgar) Ellipsis of the dog's bollocks.

verbs.description: bollocks (third-person singular simple present bollockses, present participle bollocksing, simple past and past participle bollocksed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Britain, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, vulgar, slang) To break.
(transitive, Britain, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, vulgar, slang) (also bollocks up) To fail (a task); to make a mess of.
third-person singular simple present indicative form of bollock
